title: Newtons third law - pushing on different masses

content.question: A <math alttext="1 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></math> box rests on a horizontal floor, up against a wall. A student then pushes the box such that the box exerts a force <math alttext="F sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> on the wall, and the wall exerts a force <math alttext="F sub W 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W1</mtext></msub></math> on the box. Next, the student replaces the <math alttext="1 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></math> box with a <math alttext="2 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></math> box and pushes it such that the box exerts a force <math alttext="F sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> on the wall, and the wall exerts a force <math alttext="F sub W 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W2</mtext></msub></math> on the box. There is negligible friction between the boxes and the floor. Which of the following statements correctly compares <math alttext="F sub W 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W1</mtext></msub></math> to <math alttext="F sub W 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W2</mtext></msub></math> and provides a correct justification?

choices.label: <math alttext="F sub W 2 is greater than F sub W 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W2</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W1</mtext></msub></math> because the weight of the <math alttext="2 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></math> box is greater than that of the <math alttext="1 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></math> box.

<math alttext="F sub W 2 is greater than F sub W 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W2</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W1</mtext></msub></math> because the normal force exerted on the <math alttext="2 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></math> box must be greater than the normal force exerted on the <math alttext="1 kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></math> box.

<math alttext="F sub W 1 equals F sub W 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W1</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W2</mtext></msub></math> because the force that the wall exerts on the box has a magnitude of <math alttext="F sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> in each case.

<math alttext="F sub W 1 equals F sub W 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W1</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W2</mtext></msub></math> because the force of friction is negligible in each case.

content.answer: <math alttext="F sub W 1 equals F sub W 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W1</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>W2</mtext></msub></math> because the force that the wall exerts on the box has a magnitude of <math alttext="F sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> in each case.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
